utterances: Thank you, Liane.
Good morning.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
Donald Trump is fighting the media and, not for the first time, it's conservative media.
The historically conservative union leader of New Hampshire denounced Trump.
An editorial says Trump's presidential campaign, quote, ""insults New Hampshire voters' intelligence."" The publisher went on to call to Trump a crude blowhard with no clear political philosophy.
Trump's reply was clear enough.
He says the paper is failing and that the publisher is a loser.
It's MORNING EDITION.
The United States military manages about 30 million acres of land across this country.
That's a combined area bigger than the state of Pennsylvania.
Large portions of that land are critical habitat for rare species.
And environmentalists see an opportunity here.
Here's Will Stone of member station KJZZ in Phoenix.
Clear.
A bombing range may seem like the last place to find pockets of undisturbed ecosystems.
But take a flight around the Barry M.
Goldwater Range outside Phoenix and you'd be hard-pressed to find scorched earth.
It's one of the best places for a habitat for a Sonoran Desert species.
Ian Dowdy is riding in a small prop airplane.
Below, the arid valley stretches across wrinkled mountains into farmland, finally giving way to a succession of subdivisions.
Dowdy is a fan of what the military does here.
The only operate and use about 5 percent of this entire ground.
But the rest of it remains wild and open and available for wildlife.
That link between the environment and military is what Dowdy's organization, the Sonoran Institute, hopes to leverage.
It's spearheading a plan that would restrict development on pieces of public land around the range, mostly by designating them as federal conservation areas.
Dowdy says if you compare the flight corridors for jets to those used by wildlife on the ground...
Yesterday, we talked with the authors of a new book called Tiger Force, which tells the story of an elite U.S.
Army platoon in Vietnam that spiraled violently out of control in 1967.
John Ratliff(ph), a listener in Hillsboro, Oregon, wrote in to complain.
(Reading) ""We never hear the actions of exemplary units in Vietnam.
I was a member of the 37th Aerospace Rescue and Recovery Squadron in 1970 and '71.
We had many missions, which resulted in over 600 lives saved.
During the 11 years of conflict, air rescue service personnel were credited with saving 4,120 lives.
Why can't you also discuss some of the real heroes of Vietnam?
I think this is a sorely needed counterpoint to stories such as the one about Tiger Force.
Our coverage yesterday of a National Security Agency's program to gather the phone records of millions of Americans brought e-mails both for and against.
Mike Nikisyk(ph), in Tucson, Arizona, was against it.
(Reading) ""It's fair to ask in what ways the NSA's authorized and unauthorized anti-terrorism efforts are being expanded for other uses,"" he wrote.
Exactly which agencies are clients of this database?
What oversights and safeguards exist to keep political appointees from digesting and deploying data and analysis for political purposes?
On the other hand, Thomas Ronaine(ph), in Detroit, wrote:
(Reading) ""I firmly believe that NSA analyzing phone records is a step in the right direction.
I, and I suspect nearly everybody else in this country, have nothing to hide, and I do not care one whit if the NSA bores itself to death analyzing my records.
I do, however, care, in fact, demand that the NSA monitor and analyze every single second of every communication of any kind between any point in this country and the Middle East.
You want to look at my phone records?
Go ahead, have a ball.
Several listeners wrote in, in response to last week's show on humor and politics.
Kelly Kram(ph), in Kansas City, recalled former President Gerald Ford's appearance on Saturday Night Live.
(Reading) ""It was unbelievably funny,"" she wrote.
What a great sense of humor!
SNL has a history of landing big-name former politicians and writing them into some hilarious moments on the show.
Bob Dole and Madeleine Albright have both poked fun at themselves and spoken those iconic words, Live from New York, it's Saturday Night.
Over the weekend, that famous line was delivered by Al Gore, after several self-depreciating minutes, during which he was introduced as the President of the United States.
(Soundbite of Television show, ""Saturday Night Live"")
As for immigration, solving that came at a heavy cost, and I personally regret the loss of California.
The new Mexifornian economy is strong and el Presidente Schwarzenegger is doing a great job.
There have been some setbacks.
Unfortunately the confirmation process for Supreme Court Justice Michael Moore was bitter and divisive.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Al Gore stopping by the set of Saturday Night Live this past weekend.
The show airs, of course, on NBC.
If you have any other comments, questions, or corrections for us, the best way to reach us is by e-mail.
The address is talk@npr.org.
Please let us know where you're writing from and give us some help on how to pronounce your name.
Nick Fugate has an intellectual disability.
A few decades ago, he might've been institutionalized.
But now in many states Medicaid is supposed to help people like Fugate live on their own.
In Kansas, where Fugate lives, there's a long wait list for Medicaid services.
From KCUR in Kansas City, Alex Smith reports.

At his apartment in suburban Kansas City, 42-year-old Nick Fugate catches up on washing dishes and remembers the 22 years he spent doing it at a local hotel trying to stay on top of a never-ending stream of plates, glasses and silverware.
I mean, there was nothing easy.
I mean, I constantly had to, like, scrape - just scrape the dishes off, you know, to get it clean.
The long days, the hot kitchen, his fingers pruning in the water, it could get tedious.
But Nick says he didn't mind.
You know, just as long as I got the job done, it was fine.
It wasn't glamorous, but Nick's father Ron Fugate says the dishwashing job was the key to the self-reliance he always wanted for his son.
Having a job, being independent, participating in the community, paying taxes, being a good citizen, I think that's the dream parents have for their children in general.
All of that changed last year when Nick lost his job and did something he'd never done before.
He enrolled in Medicaid.
It's the government health insurance for Kansans who are low income or have disabilities.
It landed him on a waiting list.
And while he's waiting, he's paying out-of-pocket for job coaching, transportation and help buying groceries.
At a thousand dollars a month, it's quickly burning through his life savings.
This year, lots of Kansans like the Fugates have been speaking out at forums like this one in Kansas City.
I have had a client that has had six care coordinators, and three of them she never even met.
Thank you very much.
I'm hearing a pattern on some of these responses.
The state's been gathering feedback because it needs the federal government's permission to continue running KanCare, what the state calls Medicaid.
In 2013, Republican Governor Sam Brownback put Medicaid under the management of three private companies.
He promised this would improve services, cut waste and save enough money to end the waitlist for the kind of services Nick Fugate needs.
But the list Fugate is on hasn't gone away.
It's actually grown by a few hundred to about 3,500.
Brandt Haehn is the state's commissioner for Home and Community Based Services.
I think everybody in the system is doing the best job that they can do in order to provide the people services.
Haehn says an end to the waiting list is in sight.
In August, the state announced it had eliminated another waiting list, the one for physical disability services.

But Haehn acknowledges that developmental disability cases are more expensive and complicated, and it will take more time to find the estimated $1.5 billion the state will need to eliminate the waitlist through 2025.
As we head into the holiday season, and our attention turns to the end of the year, the NPR Music team is getting a jump on the end of the decade.

They have been listening back to music from the last 10 years and have put together a list of what they call The Decade's 50 Most Important Recordings, albums that the NPR Music folks consider game-changers, that signaled some sort of shift in the way music is made or sounds or that were especially influential.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""THE REAL SLIM SHADY"")
(Rapping) 'Cuz I'm Slim Shady, yes, I'm the real Shady.
All you other Slim Shadys are just imitating.
Eminem is on the list with the ""Marshall Mathers LP"" from 2000, and so is Yo-Yo Ma with his ""Silk Road Journeys"" from 2002.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Music critic and ALL THINGS CONSIDERED contributor Tom Moon helped compile the list.
He joins me now to talk about a few more of the selections.
Hey, Tom.
Hi.
And we're going to start with the only band that has two entries on this list.
That's the British group Radiohead.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""EVERYTHING IN ITS RIGHT PLACE"")
This is a song called ""Everything in Its Right Place"" from ""Kid A"" which came out in the year 2000.

They, in a sense, owned the decade in terms of sort of the cutting edge of rock music and the blending of rock music and electronica and the notion of how to orchestrate and sort of get away from this guitar, bass, drums.
